description: This course is an introduction to the basic concepts and standards underlying financial accounting systems. Several important concepts will be studied in detail, including: revenue recognition, inventory, long-lived assets, present value, and long term liabilities. The course emphasizes the construction of the basic financial accounting statements - the income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow statement - as well as their interpretation.
name: PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTING

values.comments: This course is an introduction to the basic concepts and standards underlying financial accounting systems. Several important concepts will be studied in detail, including: revenue recognition, inventory, long-lived assets, present value, and long term liabilities. The course emphasizes the construction of the basic financial accounting statements - the income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow statement - as well as their interpretation.   While most students supported the view of accounting as generally a “rather boring” subject, many agreed that Professor Reis made the best of it. According to one reviewer, the professor “turned accounting into a stimulating topic by bringing in real firms and teaching how the financial documents are used.” Others echoed these sentiments; one student wrote that Professor Reis “showed us the meaning behind the numbers through live examples in a way that made me want to go to class.”   Reviews of Professor Reis were largely positive; he was described as “engaging,” “very personable,” and, according to one student, “one of the most dedicated and caring professors I have had at Penn.” The professor was almost uniformly lauded for his “engaging” teaching style and his willingness to work with students outside of class in office hours, during lunches, or even via Skype.   Students were nevertheless divided in their opinions of the course’s difficulty and grading scale. While one reviewer wrote that “Professor Reis was the most fair professor I have ever had at Penn,” another commented that the grading curve was “pretty harsh,” and a third student hoped that the professor might “reevaluate how reasonable the tests are.”
